[[Coalition of Socialist Forces]] |international = [[International Socialist Tendency]] |website = http://www.e-socialists.net/ |colorcode = red }} The '''Revolutionary Socialists''' ({{lang-ar|Ø§ÙØ§Ø´ØªØ±Ø§ÙÙÙÙ Ø§ÙØ«ÙØ±ÙÙÙ}}; {{IPA-arz|elÊeÊteÉ¾Ë¤ÉkejËjiËn essÃ¦wÉ¾ejËjiËn|lang}}) (RS) are a [[Trotskyism|Trotskyist]] organisation in [[Egypt]] aligned with the [[International Socialist Tendency]].{{cite web | url=http://links.org.au/taxonomy/term/537 | title=Revolutionary Socialists (Egypt) | publisher=Links International Journal of Socialist Renewal | accessdate=7 February 2011 }} According to [[Mark LeVine]], a professor of history at the [[University of California]], the RS "played a crucial role organising [[Tahrir Square|Tahrir]] (during the [[Egyptian Revolution 2011|Egyptian Revolution]] of 2011) and now in the [[Labour movement|workers movement]]" post-[[President of Egypt|President]] [[Hosni Mubarak]].{{cite web | url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/opinion/2011/05/20115910100577565.html | title=Breathless in Egypt | publisher=Al Jazeera | date=10 May 2011 | accessdate=11 May 2011 }} They are currently involved in establishing the [[Workers Democratic Party]]{{cite web | url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/401570 | title=Labor activists organize despite legal hurdles | publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm | date=15 April 2011 | accessdate=16 April 2011 }} and the [[Coalition of Socialist Forces]].{{cite web | url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/11968/Egypt/Politics-/Egypts-leftist-front,-will-it-survive.aspx | title=Egypt's leftist front, will it survive? | publisher=Ahram Online | date=12 May 2011 | accessdate=18 May 2011 }} Leading RS members include engineer and [[Wage labour|labour]] activist [[Kamal Khalil]] and sociologist [[Sameh Naguib]].{{cite web | url=http://socialistworker.org/2011/02/23/interview-with-egyptian-socialist | title=Conversation with an Egyptian socialist | publisher=Socialist Worker (US) | date=23 February 2011 | accessdate=26 February 2011 }} Other prominent members include journalists [[Hossam el-Hamalawy]]{{cite web | url=http://mrzine.monthlyreview.org/2011/hamalawy080211.html | title=Revolution 2.0: Interview with Hossam el-Hamalawy | publisher=MRZine | date=8 February 2011 | accessdate=10 February 2011 }} and [[Gigi Ibrahim]].{{cite web | url=http://www.socialistworker.co.uk/art.php?id=24165 | title=Socialist from Egypt to join debate about revolution | publisher=Socialist Worker (UK) | date=12 March 2011 | accessdate=19 March 2011}}{{cite news | url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748703561604576150604132131990.html | title=Splits Emerge Among Egypt's Young Activists | publisher=The Wall Street Journal | date=18 February 2011 | accessdate=15 March 2011 | first=Charles | last=Levinson }} The organisation produces a newspaper called ''[[The Socialist]]''. ==History== The group began in the late 1980s among small circles of students influenced by [[Trotskyism]]. Adopting the current name by April 1995, the RS grew from a few active members, when the Egyptian left was very much underground,{{cite web | url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/375053 | title=What's left of Egypt's Left | publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm | date=26 March 2011 | accessdate=27 March 2011 }} to a couple of hundred by the [[Second Intifada|Second Palestinian Intifada]]. Despite not being able to freely organise under [[Egyptian President|President]] [[Hosni Mubarak]],{{cite web | url=http://www.socialistworker.co.uk/art.php?id=23782 | title=Egyptian revolutionary: âWe are changed foreverâ | publisher=Socialist Worker (UK) | date=1 February 2011 | accessdate=8 February 2011 }}{{cite web | url=http://www.socialistworker.co.uk/art.php?id=23945 | title=Egyptian socialists: 'This won't stop at Mubarak' | publisher=Socialist Worker (UK) | date=15 February 2011 | accessdate=1 March 2011 }} the group's membership still increased due to their participation in the Palestinian solidarity movement. The intifada was seen to have a radicalising effect on Egyptian youth, which in turn helped to re-establish [[grass roots]] activism, which had long been repressed under the Mubarak regime. The RS' relationship with the outlawed [[Muslim Brotherhood]] is also distinct from earlier leftist organisations in Egypt which held similar positions to that of the [[Egyptian Communist Party]], which generally equated [[Islamism]] with [[fascism]]. The RS however, advanced the slogan "Sometimes with the Islamists, never with the [[State (polity)|state]]". The slogan was coined by [[Chris Harman]] of the [[Socialist Workers Party (Britain)|Socialist Workers Party]] of [[United Kingdom|Britain]], in his book, ''The Prophet and the Proletariat'',{{cite web | url=http://www.marxists.de/religion/harman/pt09.htm | title=The prophet and the proletariat | publisher=REDS â Die Roten | year=1994 | accessdate=8 February 2011 }} which was translated into [[Arabic]], and widely distributed by the RS in 1997. The RS has thus been able to campaign alongside the Brotherhood at times, for example, during the pro-intifada and anti-war movements.{{cite web | url=http://www.mafhoum.com/press10/300S24.htm | title=Comrades and Brothers | publisher=Middle East Report | date=7 February 2011 | accessdate=8 February 2011 }} ==2011 Egyptian Revolution== {{multiple image | width1 = 152 | width2 = 170 | align = | footer = From left to right: RS activists [[Hossam el-Hamalawy]] (AKA ''3arabawy'' ) and [[Gigi Ibrahim]] in [[Tahrir Square]] on 1 February 2011.{{cite web |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/features/2011/02/2011217134411934738.html |title=Women of the revolution |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=19 February 2011 |accessdate=13 April }} | image1 = Hossam El Hamalawy (AKA 3arabawy) tweeting.jpg | image2 = A female protester with her camera and a flower.jpg }} The RS, along with the rest of the Egyptian [[far left]] and the [[April 6 Youth Movement]], played a key role in mobilising for January 25, 2011, marking the first day of the [[2011 Egyptian Revolution|Egyptian Revolution]]. The various forces previously met and developed strategies, such as demonstrating in different parts of [[Cairo]] simultaneously, before marching on [[Tahrir Square, Cairo|Tahrir Square]], to avoid a concentration of security forces. The RS later issued a statement calling on Egyptian workers to instigate a [[general strike]] in the hope of finally ousting Mubarak: :''The regime can afford to wait out the sit-ins and demonstrations for days and weeks, but it cannot last beyond a few hours if workers use strikes as a weapon. Strike on the railways, on public transport, the airports and large industrial companies! Egyptian workers, on behalf of the rebellious youth and on behalf of the blood of our martyrs, join the ranks of the revolution, use your power and victory will be ours! :''Glory to the martyrs! :''Down with the system! :''All power to the people! :''Victory to the revolution! {{cite web | url=http://socialistworker.org/2011/02/07/call-from-egyptian-socialists | title=A call from Egyptian socialists | publisher=Socialist Worker (US) | date=7 February 2011 | accessdate=7 February 2011 }} [[Gigi Ibrahim]], an RS activist, claimed the revolution had been brewing since the Second Intifada of 2000. ==Post Mubarak== In the aftermath of Mubarak's resignation as President, the RS is calling for [[permanent revolution]].{{cite web | url=http://socialistworker.org/2011/03/15/making-the-revolution-permanent | title=Making the revolution permanent | publisher=Socialist Worker (US) | date=15 March 2011 | accessdate=19 March 2011 }} On [[May Day]] 2011, they chanted "A workersâ revolution against the [[Supreme Council of the Armed Forces|capitalist government]]", while marching to Tahrir Square.{{cite web | url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/11188/Egypt/Politics-/Egypts-May-Day-celebrations-end-on-sour-note.aspx | title=Egypt's May Day celebrations end on sour note | publisher=Ahram Online | date=2 May 2011 | accessdate=5 May 2011 }} They argue that the [[proletariat|working class]], particularly of Cairo, [[Alexandria (Egypt)|Alexandria]] and [[Mansoura]] were the key players in ousting Mubarak, rather than the Egyptian youths' use of [[social networking]] sites, such as [[Facebook]] and [[Twitter]], as has been widely reported.{{cite web | url=http://socialistworker.org/2011/02/18/egypts-spreading-strikes | title=Egypt's spreading strikes | publisher=Socialist Worker (US) | date=18 February 2011 | accessdate=26 February 2011 }} The RS sees the role of the Muslim Brotherhood post-Mubarak as "[[counter-revolutionary]]".{{cite web | url=http://www.swp.ie/reviews/interview-hisham-fouad-revolutionary-socialists-egypt/4487 | title=Interview with Hisham Fouad from Revolutionary Socialists of Egypt | publisher=Socialist Worker (Ireland) | date=27 May 2011 | accessdate=29 May 2011 }} In March 2011, RS activist and journalist [[Hossam el-Hamalawy]] was among many protesters who stormed and seized offices of the [[State Security Investigations Service]] in [[Nasr City]]. The building had been used prior to the revolution to detain and [[torture]] many activists. El-Hamalawy was able to visit the cell where he had been imprisoned, later writing on his Twitter feed that he could not stop crying.{{cite news | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/10/world/middleeast/10cairo.html?hp | title=Egyptians Get View of Extent of Spying | publisher=The New York Times | date=9 March 2011 | accessdate=12 April 2011 | first1=Liam | last1=Stack | first2=Neil | last2=MacFarquhar }} "Entered the small compound where I was locked. Man, I can't believe it still... Many are literally crying. We can't find the interrogation rooms. This is a citadel."{{cite web | url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/spotlight/anger-in-egypt/2011/03/2011368410372200.html | title=A first step towards prosecutions? | publisher=Al Jazeera | date=6 March 2011 | accessdate=12 April 2011 }} The RS calls for the dismantling of the ruling [[Supreme Council of the Armed Forces|Military Council]], the [[Egyptian Army|army]] and [[Law enforcement in Egypt|police force]], and for Mubarak and his former regime, including [[Mohamed Hussein Tantawi]] and [[Sami Hafez Anan]], (who currently form part of the Military Council) to stand trial.{{cite web | url=http://www.socialistworker.co.uk/art.php?id=24469 | title=Egyptian socialists on the state attacks on protesters in Tahrir Square | publisher=Socialist Worker (UK) | date=10 April 2011 | accessdate=11 April 2011 }} They oppose the [[decree-law]] that criminalises strikes, protests, demonstrations and sit-ins imposed by the Council on March 24, 2011.{{cite web | url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/8484/Egypt/Politics-/Egypt-protests-against-antiprotest-law-.aspx | title=Egypt protests against anti-protest law | publisher=Ahram Online | date=24 March 2011 | accessdate=11 April 2011 }} The RS along with many other Egyptian leftist organisations are also seeking to establish a new [[vanguard party|workers party]] in the wake of Mubarak's downfall.{{cite web | url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/6466/Egypt/Politics-/New-Leftist-party-being-assembled-in-Egypt.aspx | title=New Leftist party being assembled in Egypt | publisher=Ahram Online | date=26 February 2011 | accessdate=1 March 2011 }} The party, named the [[Workers Democratic Party]], aims to have "workers as the main players and leaders of the party joined by a number of intellectuals".{{cite web | url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/6863/Egypt/Politics-/January-Revolution-generates-a-new-Egyptian-politi.aspx | title=January Revolution generates a new Egyptian political map | publisher=Ahram Online | date=4 March 2011 | accessdate=8 March 2011 }} The establishment of such a party in Egypt is still illegal under the current government with the new [[Political Parties Law]] issued on March 29, 2011, where the establishment of [[Social class|class]]-based parties is strictly prohibited. [[Kamal Khalil]] - a leading RS member - responded by saying they are not concerned of the legality of the party: "We don't want a party based on paper, we want a party based in factories and workplaces". On May 10th, 2011, the RS along with four other left-wing Egyptian groups united to form a "socialist front" called the [[Coalition of Socialist Forces]], which includes the [[Popular Democratic Alliance Party]], [[The Socialist Party of Egypt]], the [[Egyptian Communist Party]] and the [[Workers Democratic Party]].{{cite web | url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/11855/Egypt/Politics-/Five-socialist-parties-unite-to-impact-Egyptian-po.aspx | title=Five socialist parties unite to impact Egyptian politics | publisher=Ahram Online | date=11 May 2011 | accessdate=18 May 2011 }} ==Positions on international issues== In 2006, [[Sameh Naguib]] - a leading RS member - labeled [[Hezbollah]]'s defeat of the [[Israeli Defense Forces|Israeli Defence Forces]] in the [[2006 Lebanon War|Lebanon War]] "a very important victory for the [[anti-war movement]] worldwide", claiming it prevented or delayed [[US]] and [[Israel]]i plans to attack [[Iran]] and [[Syria]].{{cite web | url=http://www.socialistworker.co.uk/art.php?id=9521 | title=Sameh Naguib in Egypt: âIsraelâs defeat has transformed the regionâ | publisher=Socialist Worker (UK) | date=26 August 2006 | accessdate=9 May 2011 }} On March 2, 2011, during the US [[2011 Wisconsin budget protests|Wisconsin budget protests]], the RS sent a message of solidarity to the US [[International Socialist Organization]], urging them to build "a revolutionary socialist alternative" against "[[Zionism]] and [[imperialism]]".{{cite web | url=http://socialistworker.org/2011/03/02/solidarity-from-egyptian-socialists | title=Solidarity message from Egyptian socialists | publisher=Socialist Worker (US) | date=2 March 2011 | accessdate=3 March 2011 }} The RS were amongst many socialists who condemned the [[Robert Mugabe]] regime of [[Zimbabwe]] for arresting and torturing [[militant]]s, amongst who were members of Zimbabwe's [[International Socialist Organisation (Zimbabwe)|International Socialist Organisation]], for hosting a meeting discussing the revolutions in [[Tunisian revolution|Tunisia]] and [[2011 Egyptian revolution|Egypt]]. They said "[t]he masses in Tunisia and Egypt have proven that no matter how long [[Autocracy|autocratic regimes]] last, the revolution's earthquake can break the walls and dams. Be sure that the earthquake is coming and that Mugabe will fall--".{{cite web | url=http://socialistworker.org/2011/03/28/mugabe-regime-feels-pressure | title=Mugabe regime feels pressure | publisher=Socialist Worker (US) | date=29 March 2011 | accessdate=30 March 3, 2011 }} On March 20, 2011, during the [[2011 Libyan civil war|Libyan uprising]], the RS condemned the [[UN Security Council]], the [[European Union]] and the [[Obama Administration]] on their decision to implement a [[No-Fly Zone]] and [[Peacekeeping|foreign military intervention]] in [[Libya]] as "part of the counter-revolution." They accused them of remaining silent "for decades while [[Gaddafi]], and his like among the [[Arab world|Arab regimes]], suppressed their people with the utmost brutality and piled up wealth... so long as these regimes implemented the recommendations of the [[International Monetary Fund]] for the abolition of any [[Welfare|social support]] for the poor... as long as companies kept open their doors to global [[capitalism]]...".{{cite web | url=http://www.socialistworker.co.uk/art.php?id=24398 | title=Egyptian socialists on Libya, foreign intervention and counter-revolution | publisher=Socialist Worker (UK) | date=2 April 2011 | accessdate=6 April 2011 }} ==See also== * [[Socialism]] * [[Marxism]] * [[Trotskyism]] * [[International Socialist Tendency]] * [[List of Trotskyist internationals]] * [[Tony Cliff]] * [[Workers' Councils]] == References == {{Reflist|2}} == External links == * [http://www.e-socialists.net/ Revolutionary Socialists] - Official website of the RS * [http://www.scribd.com/doc/13253184/The-Socialist-32- An issue of ''The Socialist''] - Paper of the RS (Arabic) * [http://twitter.com/#!/eSocialists Revolutionary Socialists's account on Twitter] {{Egyptian Revolution of 2011}} {{2010â2011 Middle East and North Africa protests}} {{Egyptian political parties}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Revolutionary Socialists}} [[Category:2011 in Egypt]] [[Category:2011 riots]] [[Category:Activism]] [[Category:Anti-Zionism in Egypt]] [[Category:Banned communist parties]] [[Category:Communist parties in Egypt]] [[Category:2011 Egyptian revolution]] [[Category:Far-left politics]] [[Category:International Socialist Tendency]] [[Category:Political parties established in 1995]] [[Category:Political parties in Egypt]] [[Category:Socialist parties]] [[Category:Politics of Egypt]] [[Category:Protests in Egypt]] [[Category:Riots and civil disorder in Egypt]] [[Category:Trotskyist organisations]] [[ar:Ø§ÙØ§Ø´ØªØ±Ø§ÙÙÙÙ Ø§ÙØ«ÙØ±ÙÙÙ (ÙØµØ±)]]
